newsitem.title: Zaire: Opposition picks Mobutu rival as Zaire premier.
newsitem.headline: Opposition picks Mobutu rival as Zaire premier.

text.p: Zaire's bickering opposition said on Tuesday it had nominated an arch-foe of President Mobutu Sese Seko as the country's new prime minister.

After a week of bitter wrangling the USORAL opposition alliance voted overwhelmingly for the appointment of veteran politician Etienne Tshisekedi as replacement for prime minister Kengo wa Dondo, who resigned a week ago.
"We have just designated Mr Tshisekedi wa Malumba as prime minister," USORAL leader Frederic Kibassa told the pro-Mobutu presidential Movement in parliament.
Presidential Movement leader Idambituo Bakata indicated Mobutu would endorse the appointment of the man he sacked as prime minister in December 1992.

"I would like to express my great joy, the joy, I think, of all the nation, for the simple fact that today you have given us a conclusion that many of our citizens were waiting for," Bakata said on the nomination.
Tshisekedi, 64, has huge popular support in Zaire and has long favoured talks with rebels who have seized a quarter of the country since taking up arms last October.
But with rebels keeping up pressure on the battlefield while preparing for negotiations, even some of Tshisekedi's staunchest supporters say he could be Mobutu's last prime minister.

Rebel leader Laurent Kabila has made clear that he will not accept politicians who collaborate with Mobutu in a transitional government Kabila hopes will be formed after negotiations due to start in South Africa at the weekend.
Under Zaire's transitional constitution, the presidential movement which forms the majority in parliament, has to approve the nomination before Mobutu formally signs it into law.
Senior politicians in both camps said they expected the nomination to sail through both stages.
Parliament voted nearly two weeks ago to oust Kengo, a part-Tutsi who has been widely denounced for weakness in dealing with the rebellion spearheaded by ethnic Tutsis.
Banyamulenge Tutsis took up arms in October after local authorities tried to expel them to their ancestral homeland in Rwanda. Rebels have captured key towns in east and south Zaire.
